preview.0: The symbols, mottos, and small objects added to the agency's newest Mars rover serve a variety of purposes, from functional to decorative.
preview.1: A new paper identifies a ring of minerals at the rover's landing site that are ideal for fossilizing microbial life.
preview.2: Sensors on NASA's Perseverance will help prepare for future human exploration by taking weather measurements and studying dust particles.
preview.3: During this next phase, the program will mature critical technologies and make critical design decisions as well as assess industry partnerships.
preview.4: Marking its 15th anniversary since launch, one of the oldest spacecraft at the Red Planet has provided glimpses of dust devils, avalanches, and more.
preview.5: Stacking spacecraft components on top of each other is one of the final assembly steps before a mission launches to the Red Planet.
preview.6: Efforts to save the heat probe continue.
preview.7: Winners include the JPL-managed "Send Your Name to Mars" campaign, NASA's Global Climate Change website and Solar System Interactive.
preview.8: The pair of briefcase-sized satellites made history when they sailed past Mars in 2019.
preview.9: New evidence suggests salty, shallow ponds once dotted a Martian crater — a sign of the planet's drying climate.
preview.10: Jim Bridenstine addresses NASA's ambitious plans for the coming years, including Mars Sample Return.
preview.11: The agency's new Mars rover is put through a series of tests in vacuum chambers, acoustic chambers and more to get ready for the Red Planet.
preview.12: Listen to the marsquakes and other, less-expected sounds that the Mars lander has been detecting.
preview.13: After the rover was shipped from JPL to Kennedy Space Center, the team is getting closer to finalizing the spacecraft for launch later this summer.
preview.14: After more than a year in the "clay-bearing unit," Curiosity is making a mile-long journey around some deep sand so that it can explore higher up Mount Sharp.
